Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
```C
// For second half of image, take information from tempArray
        for (int j = 0; j > width / 2; j++)```  this seems wrong.     I might suggest you've overcomplicated it a bit.  How about just iterating over the original image, swapping the first half of pixels on each line with the second half and storing those in a temp array (full size)?  then at the end, copy the entire temp back to the original.

I mean, if you have

1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8

then you can swap  1  and 8, 2 and 7, 3 and 6, 4 and 5  to end up with

8 7 6 5 4 3 2 1

Author: chriso#1172
Content:
hey guys can anyone help me understand what this does
RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width] = calloc(height, width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));
I get the calloc part
but what is RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width]

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you're declaring a 2 dimensional array of RGBTRIPLEs called `image`

Author: chriso#1172
Content: ahh

Author: chriso#1172
Content: so its shorthand for RGBTRIPLE image[height][width] ?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: not so much shorthand, but declaring it on the heap versus on the stack (as the other does)

Author: chriso#1172
Content: thanks man ill go back and watch the stack vid

Author: chriso#1172
Content: hey guys im still having trouble understanding what this line of code does

Author: chriso#1172
Content: RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width] = calloc(height, width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));

Author: chriso#1172
Content: i get that its creating a 2 d array called image pointing to a block of memory

Author: chriso#1172
Content: but RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width] looks like a 1 dimensional array image[width]

Author: chriso#1172
Content: how does height come into it and why is height in calloc(height, width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: let's say the image is 4x4 bitmap.  Each "row" needs 12 bytes (because an RGBTRIPLE takes 3 bytes).  Your calloc will allocate 48 bytes of memory and return the address of the first byte in that memory.  When you then `fread(image[0], ...)` the 12 bytes from the file will be stored at that address.  Then `fread(image[1], ...)` will, because of pointer arithmetic, be put into the 13th slot of the memory, etc. until the loop finishes and you've put all 16 pixels into the array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you were going to use stack memory instead, you could just declare it as a 2d array:  ```RGBTRIPLE image[height][width]```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ```RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width] = calloc(height, width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));``` is the exact same, but using heap memory

Author: chriso#1172
Content: so im just reading trying to understand ill ask some questions in a bit, really appreciate you helping like this

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
chriso#1172
Content:
so in int (*num2)[width] = calloc(height, width * sizeof(int)); 
its declaring an array of ints starting at the address num2

Author: chriso#1172
Content: so it would be 1 dimensional if calloc(width * sizeof(int));

Author: chriso#1172
Content: so declaration of the second dimension of the array actually happens here calloc(height, width * sizeof(int));

Author: chriso#1172
Content: so if you used malloc you could do it the exact same way it just wouldn't initialise the array prefilled with 0s as calloc does

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if it was one dimensional, you'd say ```int *num2 = calloc(1, width * sizeof(int));```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: This sort of stuff isn't really covered in the course as it goes beyond what we expect you to learn about the intricacies of C programming. ðŸ™‚

Author: chriso#1172
chriso#1172
Content: ok sorry, thanks for answering though

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `int *num = calloc(sizeof(int));` will give you enough memory for one integer

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: well, it will declare a pointer to one integer.

Author: chriso#1172
Content: cool I understand it a lot more now. Thank you.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: just a correction:  `int *num = calloc(1, sizeof(int));`   (calloc takes two arguments)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `int *num = malloc(sizeof(int));`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it's very similar to  `char *word = malloc(10);`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: would give you space for 10 chars, just like `char word[10];`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `int *num = malloc(10 * sizeof(int));`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: would be like `int num[10];`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and to get back to Filter, we use the heap for the array because the stack memory is limited and many bitmaps might be larger than can be stored on the stack

Author: chriso#1172
Content: I thought the stack would continue to fill into the heap anyway?

Author: chriso#1172
Content: or is there a limit to how much we can store on the stack in relation to the heap

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the size of the stack is implementation specific. In the CS50 IDE, it is 8MB max

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you try to push more than that, you'll get a stack overflow

Author: chriso#1172
Content: ah thanks man

Author: pabLowe#6990
Content: @Bobby let's say you are blurring top left pixel. You can make additional nested for loops to iterate over 3x3 array around the pixel - in that case you have array from -1 to 1 over height and -1 to 1 over width. You can simply check  with if statement if pixels' coordinates, that you want to iterate through, exists (if lets say for image[x][y] x>= 0 && x<= height - 1 && y >= 0 && y <= width - 1) and if not, just skip them

Author: Bobby#3076
Content: First I made an empty array by doing RGBTRIPLE blur[height][width] and initialized variables for red, green and blue to zero.  Then I made 4 for loops, each one inside the other. The outside two loops iterate through the pixels of the image and the two loops inside only go from -1 to 1 and iterate through 9 pixels (the current pixel and the 8 surrounding it.) Then inside all those loops I made an if statement that said... if the pixel in the 3x3 grid exists (that is, if its i is between 0 and height - 1 and its j is between 0 and width - 1, then add the red, green, and blue values to the sums and iterate a square counter. Finally, divide the sums by the square counter, round, and add that pixel to the empty array I made. At the very end, copy that array back into the image array.

Author: ambergristle#9460
Content: @AbhijithGo check50 tests whether a set of pixels match expected BGR values. In this case, check50 expected some pixel to have values B:0 G:0 R:255. When reflecting a test 1x2 image, your function assigned that pixel the value B:3 G:0 R:0, triggering the error message. Without knowing more about how you assigned pixels their new values, it's hard to say why the pixel values are being misassigned.

Author: AbhijithGo#2607

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Deleted User If you're still with the blur code, make sure to not access any pixels that are outside the image, you might get pixels from other rows, or access memory outside the array. Also, I think you need to process the three different colour components individually.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you shouldn't have to.   but it's that integer division problem that you may have faced in readability

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: divide by 3.0 instead to force a floating point calculation

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
say that you've added it to 287.   
287/3 is 95.  
287/3.0 is 95.66667  which rounds to 96.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you put that +1, you'd have 288/3 which is 96

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Correct. In technical writing, this is often called "rounds towards zero", as opposed to floating point functions `ceil` (rounds towards positive infinity) or `floor` (rounds towards negative infinity), and of course regular `round`.

Author: Hexadius#0537
Hexadius#0537
Content: so now you know to change image[i][j-1] accoringly

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: yes

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: great!

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: Think of it this way: If the row consisted of 10 pixels and on the first iteration we want to swap first and last pixels, I imagine they would look like image[0][0] and image[0][9], right?

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: Or inside the loop: first is image[i][j] because we just started and i = 0 and j = 0, last is image[j][width - j - 1] because we can take the length of the array, which is 10, but because we start and 0 it hast to be 9

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: so we substract 1 from 10 to have the last pixel

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: but image[j][width - 1] would not work on the next iteration, right?

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: so maybe image[j][width - j]  ? It might work! But on the very first iteration j is 0. So it would be image[i][width - 0], on the next image[i][j-1]

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: It would work on the second iteration, but it's already too late, because we want to subtract 2

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: So why not subtract one more on the first iteration?

Author: Hexadius#0537
Content: and that is how we get  image[j][width - j - 1]

Content: I hope that helped. I'm bad at explaining stuff ðŸ˜„

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
You have to make all the psets green (green background for the number on cs50.me).
Unlike previous years, this time they migrated completed psets, not individual problems. I think that could have been communicated in a better way (maybe they are a bit unspecific for some flexibility), but at least it's not a total loss, affects only the pset you were working on, and some solutions like the one for `recover` can still be used. (Edit: Typo)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
@Blauelf >>> I think that could have been communicated in a better way

Point taken.  We were trying to be flexible but I think the flexibility may have caught folks unaware.  Hoping that this FAQ upfront will make it clearer come next year:  

> **I wonâ€™t be able to finish the course before 31 December 2020. What will happen?**
> After 31 December 2020, the course will be updated to a 2021 version. Your progress from 2020 will be carried forward to the 2021 version. We will (in 2021) attempt to give credit for as much of the 2021 course as is practicable, so you will not have to start from the beginning.
> 
> That said, the course does change from year to year, and some problem sets may not map from the 2020 course into the 2021 course, which may require you to double back to past assignments. For example, Problem Set 3 in CS50x 2020 has no mapping to any assignment in CS50x 2019, so students who did not finish CS50x 2019 must now complete the CS50x 2020 version of Problem Set 3, even though this may mean doubling back.
> 
> After 31 December 2020, you may only submit the 2021 versionâ€™s problem sets and will need to satisfy whatever requirements are in place for CS50x 2021.

https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/faqs/#i-wont-be-able-to-finish-the-course-before-31-december-2020-what-will-happen

Author: violinmaster27#8110
Content: Can somebody help me? Whenever I am checking my filter program it says that my grayscale function is not working properly in that it is giving wrong outputs for rounding out numbers. I am using the round function for when the decimal value of the average is greater than .5 but it is still rounding down. For example the output of 126.6666 should be 127, but it's saying my output is 126. Any suggestions??

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Do you maybe perform integer division (dividing two integers)? That one will round towards zero, ignoring the fractional part. Now if the `3` were a `3.0`, it no longer would be an integer division...
Or are you assigning your non-rounded result to an integer type? Again, it would cut off the fractional part, rounding towards zero.

Author: violinmaster27#8110
Content: wow thanks! I simply changed my 3 to 3.0 and that fixed it!

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Python2 had the same division operator, where the kind of division is determined by the operand types. Now in Python3 they have separate operators.

Content: use variables for your loops that are looking at the surrounding pixels. You can calculate the min & max offsets first, and then, you just need one nested loop to iterate over the surrounding pixels.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @violinmaster27 variables for the loops that are looping over the surrounding pixels

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: let's say you are on the top row  pixel.  You don't want to go from that pixel to the one above (y-1), since that is out of range.  Or if you're on the last pixel, you don't want to go (x+1) since that is out of range ...  so you calculate based on the current x/y position what the max/min values those can be ... then your loop can be something like `for (int x = xmin; x <= xmax; x++)`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you are iterating over the width (j), then if j is 0, you want your min x to be 0 otherwise it will be -1  (ie, moving one pixel to the left).  Does that make sense?

Author: violinmaster27#8110
Content: oh okay, so limiting it so that it doesn't go out of range of of the picture

For the sums, `int` is definitely large enough.

Author: Dalsnin#3322
Content:
@Scanners try to pack it in like this:

```
round((pixels)/n)

n = number of pixels (for example 5) and used as a FLOAT (so write 5.0 and it calculates as a float).
pixels = the addition of all the pixel values in the surrounding cells and the cell itself

```

Content: That should fix your rounding issue

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Aimer Pointers have a few use cases. You need them for passing around data you don't want to copy, maybe because it's large, or you want changes to be visible to the calling code. Or you want to allocate memory outside of the stack, so it survives the block the variable got declared in. Arrays are passed around as pointers to their first element.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: In helpers.c are we allowed to add `<stdio.h>`, `<cs50.h>` etc. at the top to utilise stuff like printf, or is that not allowed?

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: Because printf doesn't seem to work when I add it to the helpers.c code.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You may add headers. You are not supposed to add global variables (because it doesn't make much sense) or change `main` or the function signatures (because it could break the checks). Adding `printf` to `main` should be ok.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: There's a problem with writing directly to the array you read from, as you need the original value for calculating other neighbouring pixels as well. So a common approach is to define a second array, and use one for reading, one for writing, and at some point copy the content over. So either create a copy for reading, and write to the image, or write to the other array first and then copy over when everything has been blurred.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you are iterating over the image with `i` and `j`, then if `i` is 0, you set the min to 0, else it's  i-1.  if `i` is width-1, then max is width-1 else it's i+1.  And then the same sort of thing with the `j`.  What you want to avoid is copy/pasting all of your loops into lots of conditions.

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content:
@Hinkdogg this is what kiwi and I mentioned above. If you consider the logic going on in your loop, what you are doing is taking the pixel at image[i][j] and simply replacing it with image[i][(width - 1) - j]. But you are not ever actually doing anything with the original pixel image[i][j].  You are overwriting that pixelâ€™s data without ever actually moving that pixel...

Your code is just changing one pixelâ€™s value each iteration. What it needs to be doing is swapping two pixels. Try using a temporary variable to store the first pixel data, so you can then put that data into image[i][(width - 1) - j].

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: Also you really donâ€™t need to loop over the full width... if you think about what is going on, to get a mirror you only need to iterate through half of the width.

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: If you use the method I suggested and you iterate the full width, what is going to happen is the first half will mirror, but once you get to the second half of the image itâ€™ll be mirroring it right back to the original image

Author: Vince#6486
Content: for the blur filter, how do I stop it from using the new blurred pixels for the next pixels?

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: @Vince Best way to handle this is by creating a copy of the original image and use that when calculating values.

Author: Vince#6486
Content: but how would I do that just by making the function?

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: Well image is an RGBTRIPLE... you can set a new variable of type RBGTRIPLE, and just add each of the pixels from â€œimageâ€ into it. So now you have an exact copy of the original data. Use that when calculating your values, then add the â€œblurredâ€ values into the original image, leaving the copy unchanged. This way you arenâ€™t going back and using already blurred values for the next pixel.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when doing blur, you have to consider the 9 pixels in the box (ie, the 3 on the row above, the 3 on the row below, and the 3 in the middle row (including the pixel being calculated).  Using a min/max allows you to have one loop that goes from -1 to 1 but using the min/max to avoid trying to grab a pixel that doesn't exist.

Author: LBRCloud#7264
Content: how does it know it doesn't exist? how does max/min judge that?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it doesn't, but you know that you can't have `image[-1]`  or `image[height]` since both of those are outside the array bounds.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: or `image[0][-1]` or `image[0][width]`

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: Please explain me, what "padding" is and why do we skip it?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: In a BMP file, everything is aligned to addresses divisible by 4. That is, after the file header of 14 bytes, the bitmap header has a length divisible by 4, and each line has a length divisible by 4. If it doesn't, padding bytes are added to make it that long.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: last year's Resize problem has an explanation of padding (since it was relevant to the problem)  Might want to look at that?  https://docs.cs50.net/2019/x/psets/3/resize/less/resize.html

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
The condition seems wrong, I guess you would have to test `i+k` and `j+l`, not any of those variables individually.
You would have to declare some variables where you sum up the colour values over all the 4, 6, or 9 pixels. Those would have to handle values up to `9*255`, so an `int` (or even a `short`) would be fine.
I would do the averaging inside the `j` loop, after the `k` loop.
You read from and write to `image`. You would replace values you still need for calculating the average for other neighbouring pixels. You could use some array instead, so you use one for input, one for output.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The names of parameters are not part of the function signature, they are only for internal usage inside your function definition. If you write somewhere `void reflect(int height, int width, RGBTRIPLE image[height][width]);` at the top of your file, the variable names are ignored.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The compiler just cares about the types.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: are you running into integer division (ie, truncated division)?  330/9 will be 36 before you round it, for example.

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: I sum up image[i][j].rgbtRed, image[i][j].rgbtGreen and image[i][j].rgbtBlue and divide it by 3

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: and then round the result

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Do you divide by 3 (and do an integer division, as both operands are integer) or by 3.0 (floating point division since at least one operand is floating point)?

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: by 3

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Then try floating point, otherwise you round an integer, not much to round there.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: A pure integer solution would be `(red+green+blue+1)/3`, no `round`, all integers.

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: with 3.0 everything finally works, thank you â¤ï¸

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Integer divsion truncates the result, so that it is an integer again.

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: yes, now I understand

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content:
> A pure integer solution would be `(red+green+blue+1)/3`, no `round`, all integers.
@Blauelf why do you add 1 to red+green+blue?

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: in blur, can I also use integers?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Adding half the divider (or subtracting if negative) has the same effect as our definition of rounding.
```
round(0/3.0)=round(0.000)=0   0+1=1, 1/3=0
round(1/3.0)=round(0.333)=0   1+1=2, 2/3=0
round(2/3.0)=round(0.667)=1   2+1=3, 3/3=1
round(3/3.0)=round(1.000)=1   3+1=4, 4/3=1
```

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: So yes, you could perform the same trick in `blur`. I just don't think students are supposed to understand how that works.

Author: jul1aaa#4398
Content: if you hadn't explained me how that works and i hadn't understood it, i wouldn't have been able to complete this task

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The hints are probably meant to lead students to a `round`-based solution with floating point division.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: You don't have to know how to use +1 to do the rounding.  You can just use `round`.  The spec says: "The values of a pixelâ€™s rgbtRed, rgbtGreen, and rgbtBlue components are all integers, so be sure to round any floating-point numbers to the nearest integer when assigning them to a pixel value!"

Content: If that helps you get your floating point to round... `float` should support those numbers we can expect, and not do any rounding errors as in `cash`.

Content:
@Hinkdogg In your main loops, use separate arrays for reading (original) and writing (image). At the time you use the pixels in `original`, about half of them haven't been copied over yet. Copy the whole image at once before you start averaging any pixels.
And remove that `return`, and the average belongs into the second loop, after you have iterated the 3x3 window.

Author: Saber#7900
Content: Hi to anyone! Is the code for greyscale and sepia similar

Author: The Wild Haggis#1685
Content: @Saber Sepia is a very stylistic and individualistic edit. I'm a photographer and when we do sepia, it could be an entire tone on all pixels, or just through blacks, mid-tones or highlights. But if it was throughout the entire image then technically yes. Sepia is a greyscale image with the sepia tone put on top, which can be done by moving the red, blue and green a small amount throughout the image. You would have to know colour theory to get the colours right, for example move the blue pixels down by 'x' amount between 0 - 255; removing blue makes the image appear more yellow. etc. etc.

Author: The Wild Haggis#1685
Content: In short, similar but there is more code. You would need to check if each colour channel goes between 0 and 255 after the value move, and if it does then it would store the value for each channel.

Author: The Wild Haggis#1685
Content: You could even do math on the value between 0 and 255 so that depending on the value of the pixel you could add more or less sepia. Mid-tones having more of the sepia filter, blacks and whites with less.

Author: The Wild Haggis#1685
Content: your possibilities are endless lol

Author: The Wild Haggis#1685
Content: I meant different amount of sepia through black/midtones/highlights. Slapping on a sepia throughout never looks good.

Author: drail159#6376
Content: Ph  should probably be declared outside your loops with sizes [height][width], I would also suggest copying the image into ph before anything else. That way you could sample from ph and update image. Right now you are sampling from image and updating Image at the same time, that means that anytime you look at a pixel after the 1st time it's already different than the original.That's gonna mess with your average.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `tempcol.rgbtRed`  (and the other colors) is a BYTE type, as such it can't hold a value larger than 255.  If you keep adding to it, it will overflow if the sum is more than 255.  I'd suggest that you use an integer to hold your sums.

Content:
1st: You read and write the same array. But you need the neighbouring pixels' original values. Use a second array, and perform reading and writing in separate arrays, with a copy step before or after all four blurring loops.
2nd: Tiny rounding problem, as you have integer division (you might remember `readability`)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Saber `RGBTRIPLE color_red;` declares a pixel.  Each color element in that pixel  (eg, `color_red.rgbtRed` is a BYTE (8 bits)) which means it can hold a value between 0 and 255 only.   What happens if the 9 pixels in the equation all have red values of 100, say.  That would be 900.  But 900 doesn't fit in 8 bits, so the variable will overflow.  And the sum will be wrong.

Author: Saber#7900
Content: so by changing the RGBTRIPLE ... to ints itll work better?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `unsigned char` is an 8-bit integer

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it will print 32

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: because 800 in binary is `0b1100100000`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and with only 8 bits you get `00100000`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: which is 32

Author: Saber#7900
Content: hmm ok so what by changing RGB.... to int it can exceed the 8 bits?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: an int is 4 bytes

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so it can store a number > 255

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so yes, `int color_red;` would be able to hold a larger number.

Author: drail159#6376
Content: [k][l] [k][l+1] [k][l-1] [k+1][l] [k+1][l+1] [k+1][l-1] [k-1][l] [k-1][l+1] [k-1][l+1]   You would want to check that each one actually exists of course.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
@ra9 Copy the whole image in a separate set of loops, not while you are doing that. The way you are doing it, you would have to use `image` for some pixels and `newImage` for others.
Also, the averaging should happen after the two inner loops (use some `int` variables to sum up), and you should skip input pixels that are outside the image, skip in the sense that they don't get added, but also don't contribute to the divider.

Author: ra9#3988
Content: If I get you correctly I should do the copying within another loop and still maintain the four loops

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: I did it that way. Actually copied afterwards, but those versions are equivalent, whether you copy first or last.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: But copying all at once helps.

Author: ra9#3988
Content:
Sure thanks for the direction, will implement it
One thing I still don't get is with the skipping

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Your inner loops should iterate the 3x3 window around the pixel of the outer loops. Parts of this window might be outside.

Author: ra9#3988
Content: okay

Author: ra9#3988
Blauelf#6622
Content: Reset your numbers before the two inner loops. And 3x3 window only. And count the pixels you add.

Author: ra9#3988
Content: Which numbers are you referring to ?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The variables holding the sums.

Author: ra9#3988
Content: Those variables include the ones that are  holding the sum of red values, green values and blue values

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You need the sums of the 3x3 neighbourhood. So for each output pixel (outer loops), reset the sums and the pixel counter (if you use one) to 0. Then have your inner two loops iterate over that neighbourhood (ignoring the ones that are outside, either by changing the loops or checking the coordinates before adding/counting)

Author: Sheriff Kovalski#3520
Content: Can you explain why should we do image[i][width - j - 1] in reflect function?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The first pixel in row `i` is `image[i][0]`, the last pixel is `image[i][width - 1]`. As they are mirrored, the sum of the two numbers is always `width - 1`.

Content: Oh, you confused j and l

Author: Blauelf#6622

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
@snowsmith Type declarations are read from inside to outside, right to left. So we have a variable `image`, a pointer to `width` wide array of `RGBTRIPLE`.
Without the parentheses, it would be an array of `width` pointers.

Author: snowsmith#6887
Content: so in the code, it is an array of RGBTRIPLE? that's just how the syntax is?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: It's a pointer to a row of pixels. The way C allows us to use pointers and arrays same way, it works like a 2D array stored contiguously.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Not a pointer of pointers like `argv`, but a more static form with only one dereference.

Author: snowsmith#6887
Content: I guess I just don't get why there has to be the brackets (parenthesis) around `*image`

Content: That's what I said, otherwise it would be an array of pointers, not pointer to array.

Content: you can use pointers as arrays

Content:
if i do 
```
int *x = malloc(sizeof(int) * 4);

i can then access `int x[0]` to `int x[3]`

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: `x[n]` is syntactic sugar for `*(x + n)`

Author: thehorserapper#6794
Content: in c do functions loop until they receive a return value?

Author: thehorserapper#6794
Content: like return 1

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: No, they execute till they reach a return statement, unless the return type is void

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: If you don't provide a return statement, the compiler will complain

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Or if there's a chance a return statement will not be reached, it will complain

Author: thehorserapper#6794

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @gtacs The average is always between 0 and 255, so the "else" is never triggered. If it were not in range, you would not change that pixel.

Content:
The correct order would be more like
1. calculate value
2. correct value to be in range
3. use value

Author: Justin Tether#0001
Content:
I have a question not quite pertaining to filter exactly, but something that works along the lines of it

I'm doing a small program to continue brushing up on my skills while my roommates catch up and i've hit a bit of a snag

I'm taking a string in and splitting into multiple parts and adding those pointers to a char * array called args

I'm trying to iterate through args and strcmp them with a known set of operators (a char array that looks like so {"+","-","/","*"}) 

Which works, however I'm stuck where i've initialized args to a specific size (lets' say 10) and I am iterating too far through the array, as I may only have 3 or 4 strings

I do keep track of a 'commandCount' variable which tells me how many strings are split and I can use that to power my for loop, however is there a better way? Maybe dynamically increase the size of args[] with each added string? 

Or is it better to just cap off the iteration so I don't go into my garbage uninitialized portions of the array?

Author: Justin Tether#0001
Content:
Finding the size of an array isn't like i'm used to in JS where I can do .length, and even something like int arrayLength = sizeof(array) / sizeof(array[0]) doesn't work, as i've set the size of args to a specific (larger) size and it will always return that, rather than how many legit elements are inside

I thought about setting all portions of args to NULL beforehand and doing a loop and incrementing a variable for each non NULL element in args, but that also seems a bit clunky, and I can't figure out how to assign the individual values all at once like when you initialize a char array for example (like going args[10] = NULL;)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you have swap code you wrote.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but rather than calling that in a separate function, swap the actual pixels in your reflect function

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: those 3 lines of code inside your nested loop

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but with the pixel

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: not each BYTE individually

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if I have `image[i][j]` which is one of the pixels, then I can store that in a temporary RGBTRIPLE variable

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I can can then set image[i][j] equal to the reflected pixel, then set the reflected pixel to tmp and I've swapped

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if I wanted to swap the first pixel in the first row with the last pixel in the first row, and I had 3 pixels in that row... I'd set my tmp pixel to  image[0][0].  set image[0][0] to image[0][2].  set image[0][2] to tmp.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: now I have swapped the first and last pixels in the first row

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:

Content:
`RGBTRIPLE image[x][y]` means an array of dimensions `[x][y]`. Which you don't have. When calling, you are passing a regular `RGBTRIPLE` instead.
Not sure why you would move that into another function, but you would have to pass the width and height as well.

Author: TecTale#6305
Content: Hey @khalil Abraham I think one reason you are getting an error is because you are swapping the wrong pixels at line 71. As an example, for an image with a width of 600 pixels. The pixel parallel to the one at position (0, 1) is at position (0, 558).  However your script is taking width (600) - j (1) which is 559. So you are swapping (0, 1) with (0, 599) when you should be swapping it with (0, 598). You are swapping the pixel to right of the correct one.

Author: TecTale#6305
Content: in the if statement at line 98 you are allowing the script to run when the values for i + si and j + sj are equal to height and width. Remember that with arrays you start counting from 0 so an array of length 600 counts from 0 - 599. The error you are seeing is happening because you are allowing the script to run when j + sj is equal to width (600) but image[i][600] does not exist.

Author: TecTale#6305
Content: Also unrelated to the error, but you will not get the desired result if you use the original image array to add to the sum values. This is because you will be adding the modified values to the sum. If you change the pixel at position (0, 0) then use it to calculate the value of future pixels, the values for the pixels adjacent to it will be corrupted. I solved this by creating a copy of the image array at the beginning of the function and using it to add to the sums rather than the original image.

Content: @Keppke you're changing the value of the rgbt colors before you're finished using them to make the rest

Content: In other words, you use the value of rgbtRed to change rgbtRed, then you use the new value to calculate Green and then the updated values of red and green to calculate blue. You need to use the original values in each case, probably by making a new variable (sepiaRed, sepiaGreen, etc)

Author: alexpwood#8729
Content:
I solved blur first time through in a really ugly way. Trying to write a more compact solution (not sure if the whole premise of my design even makes sense...), but I'm getting some really weird behaviour inside my for loops (line 129 onwards). Starting at h = 1, w = 1 the first loop through works: it evaluates the corner "if" condition as true (line 137), calculates averages and comes back through to the top of the for loop correctly. Then for h = 1, w = 2, things get weird. It checks the if condition for corners and doesn't evaluate it as true (line 137). But then when I click to step through to my edge check condition "else if..." on line 150, h suddenly resets itself to 0 (although w keeps its correct value as 2). 

This reset ruins the program and triggers some runtime errors and other apocalyptic sounding errors, but I think it all stems from this weird little reset. 
Can anyone see why this might be happening?

Content: if you run `valgrind ./filter -b images/courtyard.bmp testblur.bmp`  does valgrind indicate why the segfault occurs?

Author: UnknownShadow#1922
Content: guys i have a question , especially i want to ask this from staff , why line 78 of filter.c is coded like this.

Author: UnknownShadow#1922
Content:
// Allocate memory for image
    RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width] = calloc(height, width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));

Author: UnknownShadow#1922
Content: image is a pointer to an array of RGBTRIPLE type with width number of elements? right

Author: UnknownShadow#1922
Content: why width ? shouldn't it be hight

Author: UnknownShadow#1922
Content: or does it matter at all

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
`image` here is a pointer to an array (in particular, an array of `RGBTRIPLE`s representing the first row of the image), which is really just the first array in a sequence of height contiguous row arrays.

In the same way that `char *` can be thought of as a whole string since it points to the first character of a string, from which we can get to the other characters; `image` here can be thought of as a pointer to the first row of an image, from which we can get to the other rows.

`calloc` is how we allocate enough memory for all of that: we need `height * width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE)` bytes to store the memory for each of the `height * width` pixels, and using `calloc` instead of `malloc` sets all of those bytes to `0` by default.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: we have `RGBTRIPLE(*image)[width]`  because we want 'width' number of elements in our row array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when we allocate memory, we allocate enough for `height * width` number of elements

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
in much the same way we can allocate a single array.  Let's say we wanted an array called `numbers` of `num` integers:  ```C
int *numbers = calloc(1, num * sizeof(int));```  will give us enough memory to hold `num` integers.    Another way to write that would be ```C
int *numbers = calloc(num, sizeof(int));``` If we were using stack memory, we could just say ```C
int numbers[num];``` to declare that.

Author: rabyte#0729
Content:
@Jrua you could try cleaning up the code a bit. For example, instead of using the if (ar > 255) part all over the place, why not write a function that would round and check the upper boundery that later can be used for everything. Also instead of creating all the special cases with similar code, you could try to put this into sub-loops (i.e. for each pixel loop all the neighbouring pixels. If some condition is met in the corners, "continue" loop without using the pixels value for the average)
Checking the code you already have, I don't think you can do afterimage[0][0].rgbtRed = ar, because ar is defined as double whereas RGBTRIPLE expects int. Anyhow after your rounding you haven an int.

Content: In reflect, why do you have to divide width by 2?

Author: Nihil Novi#0084
Content: because once you reflect one half of image, the other one is already reflected ðŸ™‚

Author: Nihil Novi#0084
Content: imagine if you have list of numbers [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Author: Nihil Novi#0084
Content: to reflect it and make it [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] you only have to swap 1 with 5 and 2 with 3

Author: Nihil Novi#0084
Content: with 4*

Author: Nihil Novi#0084
Content: len(list) = 5, and you do len(list)/2 swaps which is 2

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: First thing, your top left corner if statement doesn't look for 1, 1. It does 1, 0 twice

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: Then it looks like you swapped height and width further down.

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: Since the blur function is passed image[height][width] and you're using i to equal height and j to equal width, you need to keep it consistent within the function. You'll get [0][0], [0][width-1], [height - 1][0], and [height - 1][width- 1] for the top left, top right, bottom left, and  bottom right corners, respectively.

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: You also won't end up with any values over 255 so you can get rid of all those checks

Content: Hi guys, i am stuck on edges, am i going about this calculation the right way or not?                                                              int blue = round((gx_color_blue * gx_color_blue) + (gy_color_blue * gy_color_blue));                            int green = round((gx_color_green * gx_color_green) + (gy_color_green * gy_color_green));                                                                                                                                                            int red = round((gx_color_red * gx_color_red) + (gy_color_red * gy_color_red));

Author: Gerdi#7762
Content: @rudeen the algorithm for calculating the final value is the square root of what you're trying to round for each color.  so in general for each color channel - squareroot(Gx^2 + Gy^2)

Author: manolo#9615
Content:
yes. I spent two full days and I tell you one important thing. you have to calculate the NEW value for each pixel based ON THE OLD VALUES of the nearby 9 pixel. 

Consider you are now at position image[0][1] (lets make this very simple) you are now calculating the new color value for the SECOND PIXEL of the image BUT you have to take in consideration ONLY the original values of the nearby pixel. 

So you already modified PIXEL 1 now you are at PIXEL 2 but to change PIXEL 2 you have to take in consideration the OLD (the original) values of PIXEL 1

Author: manolo#9615
Content: Plus you have to consider the pixel values of the very same pixel you are trying to modify in the average!!!

Author: manolo#9615
Content: if you are in the middle of the image you have 8 pixel near you.  you have to consider 8 value + the very same pixel value. NOT 8 (maybe you already now this, but I was also stuck here)

Author: Thien#0976

Author: manolo#9615
Content:
look at this : int y = round(round(a+b+c)/3)); the second round is telling C "Okay whatever numbers come back from this division please round it" 
"Okay well a+b+c gives back 109.6 so im going to round it back before giving it back to you"
"Okay C, thank you"

Author: manolo#9615
Content:
if you skip the second round() you are telling C
"Hey C, do this a+b+c / 3 and then the RESULT of this expression should be rounded up"
"Okay well a+b+c gives back 109, Im a int and then am goin to round it up, hold on"
"ok Done! I rounded up 109, the result is 109 "

Author: bcunning68#7493
Content: I have created a 3X3 bitmap image to test my code and I am able to properly address each pixel and the appropriate surrounding pixels for the correct values, but I am missing something on the update.  When I update pixel [0][0] with the new values they are going into the calculation for pixel [0][1].  Missing something with pointers?

Author: Thien#0976
Content:
yes, by updating, you're assigning new value to your pixel [0][0], right?
That's why it's going into your next calculations

Author: bcunning68#7493
Content: Correct.  I was able to pass by creating a new RGBTRIPLE inside the function and then For Loop the image data to that struct, use the data from each pixel in the new struct to calculate and then update image.  Does not seem like the most elegant solution, but it just passed.

Author: jkart#9902
Content: what is the difference between initializing a new RGBTRIPLE by using calloc vs. just typing something like "RGBTRIPLE image_copy[height][width];" ?

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: calloc allocates memory on the heap and will initialise it for you

Author: zamanwahid16#0798
Content: can anyone tell me what I am doing wrong. I checked the logic. The average should be correct. But It tells me wrong

Author: jkart#9902
Content: you're probably having the same issue im having. you are placing the blurred pixel back in the same RGBTRIPLE array as the ones that still need to be blurred. therefore, future pixels are being blurred bsed on already blurred pixels, not their original values.

Author: jkart#9902
Content: ||does anyone know why this works `RGBTRIPLE (*image_copy)[width] = calloc(height, width * sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));`, but this does not `RGBTRIPLE (*image_copy)[height][width] = calloc(height * width, sizeof(RGBTRIPLE));`?||

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: Change the second to the same type as the first

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: The calloc calls are essentially the same

Content: @jkart you can, you just havent changed the calloc call appropriately, and for the purposes of this pset a 2D array of pointers isnt what you want

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: easy way to know how much memory will be allocated is to multiply both the arguments to calloc

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: if you do that, yuoll see that both your calloc calls are the same

Content: Right. So they're allocating the same amount of memory

Author: Scuwa#4614
Content: I usually round by checking whether or not the float that you want to round is higher or lower than the integer version of your float + 0.5  --- you can do this because the integer simply cuts off after the decimal point so it always rounds down. then depending on the case you output  the integer version of your float or the integer version +1

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Could also use an `if`/`else` or the ternary/conditional operator, is like if/else in the form of an expression `condition ? value1 : value2` would evaluate the condition, if it's non-zero, the result would be the first value, if it's zero/`false`, the result is the second value.
```c
int answer = false ? 23 : 42; // condition is false, so second value is used
```

Author: Graeme#0328
Content: Assuming you are looping over a 3*3 grid for every selected pixel, a mistake which i had was  incorporating  "blurred" pixels to work out the value of the average of a new blurred pixel. To make it pass the tests it has to use the value of the original pixels to calculate a blurred pixel, not blurred ones.

Author: Parminder#9117
Content:
> Assuming you are looping over a 3*3 grid for every selected pixel, a mistake which i had was not incorporating  "blurred" pixels to work out the value of the average of a new blurred pixel. To make it pass the tests it has to use the value of the original pixels to calculate a blurred pixel, not blurred ones.

Author: Henry#0397
Content:
@Ginge - potentially has something to with the fact that an image of width 5 has indexes from 0 to 4. Yet, on the first pass of j's loop (j == 0), the index `width - j` evaluates as 5, a non-valid index. This may displace the reflected image by 1 pixel

Not certain, but this my guess just looking at it

Content:

So if the sepia red, green aur blue comes out to be more than 255 for any pixel, you need to cap it to 255

Content: also, you don't have to assign the colors serpately like that. if you set a struct equal to another variable under the same struct they will take on all the values of that struct

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: so if i have a struct called "FOO temp", and i need to assign it to all the values that "FOO example" has, i don't have to go through each one and do "FOO temp = FOO example.value1" and etc. I can just do "FOO temp = FOO example" and it will take all the .values and assign it to temp

Content: @Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King Can you explain rightcount?

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Really it should be xCount

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: Why are you adding an xCount to yCount?

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: It stores the total pixels added together for any given pixel, 1:1 with xSum

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: So for image[0][1] being fed to xSum, image[0][0], [0][1], and [0][2] will be added to xSum[0][1]

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Parallel to that, rightcount[0][1] gets ++'d each time something is added to xSum[0][1]

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Which i use to determine what number to divide the final ySum by

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: The idea of this whole system is to store the sum of any pixel *and* its one/two neighbors in an array of the same size as image

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Then do a second pass and use that to fill another array, of the same size as image, setting every pixel equal to all of its neighbors added together

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: But you're working on pixel [i][j]... I don't understand why that equates to [i-1][j]?

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Sorry, which part are you talking about?

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: count += rightcount[i-1][j]

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: shouldn't that just be i j?

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Because rightcount is the exact same thing as xSum, except not for the sum of a 1x3 of pixels, but for the total pixels added together

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: You're rounding (int / int) that does nothing because it gives an int instead of a float as a value.

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: So when youre adding xSum[i-1][j] to ySum[i][j], you need to add rightcount[i-1][j] too

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: cast one to (float) and try that.

Content: And shouldn't rightcount only be added once?  Not every time you check the pixel?

Author: bocajbee#6122
Content:
```c

void grayscale(int height, int width, RGBTRIPLE image[height][width])

```

Probably a dumb question but I don't really understand the difference between the **"Height" "width"** the the 2d array **"RGBTRIPLE[][]"** arguments we're working with too. 

Like I get conceptually that:

- An image is a bitmap, comprised of a 2d array of memory addresses. 
- I'm probably going to have to use a nested loop somehow to loop through every bit/pixel from start to end, modifying it's RGB value to somehow make the whole image grey 

I just don't know:

1.  How do I make sure the red, green, and blue values are all set to the same value across every pixel (as I imagine each pixel in a complex image is going to have a stupid high amount of variety here). 

2. How do I know what value to make them?

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: "In fact, to ensure each pixel of the new image still has the same general brightness or darkness as the old image, we can take the average of the red, green, and blue values to determine what shade of grey to make the new pixel."

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: So not every pixel should be the same.  That would make the image one color.  Instead find the average of the three colors for that one pixel.

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: So for red pixels in this image red is 255.  So add 255(r) + 0(g) + 0(b) = 255.  255 / 3 = 85.  All three colors should be set to 85.

Author: bocajbee#6122
Content: Ah, by taking an average of the red green and blue values?

Author: bocajbee#6122
Content: Gotcha

Content: so if you're making a 3x3 array, you gotta do it like this array[3][3]

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: array[3][3] = { {arr1}, {arr2}, {arr3} }

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: then you fill in each subarray with the numbers you want

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: remember, when you set RGBTRIPLE to {0} it means all the colors will be set to 0 too. so that's a useful shortcut

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: you can just use int in this case

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: so you need to surround the entire thing in curly braces too

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: because it will get confused where the matrix starts and ends

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: it will evaluate whatever is within the braces

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: also don't be afraid to add new lines in between to make it easier to read in your code, your computer ignores white space so it will evaluate it all just the same

Author: maltchik#4372
Content:
For example, instead of:
int x= 5
int y= 0
round ( (x+y)/2 );

write:
float x=5
float y=0
round ( (x+y)/2.0)

Content: @curiouskiwi be sure that you declare your extra functions *before* they are called in `edges`  (ie, either by putting prototype declarations at the top of helpers.c or putting the entire function definition ahead of edges.)  remember that the compiler reads from top to bottom.

Content: i am not so sure what your problem is, but as far i can tell from your step, we are moving from i = 0 to i < height . Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: inside your box_blur function, you're running over the entirety of your image again

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: well, until it hits the end

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: technically, this is a O(n^2) algorithm, where n is the amount of pixels you have to go through

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: basically, you can make this O(n) by thinking about where the pixel you want to blur is at in the image

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: say height i, width k

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: so to get the top left pixel, you would do image[i-1][k-1]

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: to get the top pixel, it would be image[i-1][k]

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: so on and so forth

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: that would reduce your entire program to run in O(n) times

Author: Icon from asterranaut (Solancia)#4228
Content: sorry @Endovelic , I didn't read this until later

Author: freckhard#3735
Content: Is there a way for copying an RGBTRIPLE struct as a whole, or do I have to copy each struct value?

Author: freckhard#3735
Content: (without the use of memcpy or other fancy functions? â˜ºï¸ )

Author: freckhard#3735
Content: e.g. image[3][17] = fancyshmancyRGBTRIPLE;

Author: freckhard#3735
Content: because if there is not, I can just swap them manually like any value swap - I guess this is a question of efficiency? Whats more costly?

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: you can definitely copy structs. like if you set temp[i][j] = image[i][j], as long as you already declared temp as a RGBTRIPLE struct, then all the values will copy over

Author: nannergirl#5123
Content: you can even initialize them to 0 if you'd like. so if you needed all the values in temp to be 0, you could just do temp[i][j] = {0}

@pocoyo I did mine way differently. 

You can't blur on the fly, because you need to not alter the original image until later on. Otherwise you're not using the original values in your other calculations.

But the reason you need it in blur is a little different. Because the value you're changing is used again for the next pixel, so if it's changed you're not using the original value. 

This is part of where you need to think through the problem before coding.

Author: Hera#8206
Content: Hi, does break break one loop or all loops it is in?

Author: Paco#3569
Content: break escapes the current loop it's in.  If you have a j loop inside an i loop, and you break in the j loop you'll jump to the next i iteration

Author: Paco#3569
Content: (versus continue, which would just skip to the next j iteration)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
if you have an image that is 7 pixels wide and 1 high: ```
1 2 3 4 5 6 7``` and you want to reflect it, you want to swap 
1 and 7
```7 2 3 4 5 6 1```
2 and 6
```7 6 3 4 5 2 1```
3 and 5
```7 6 5 4 3 2 1
``` and you're done

Author: raweyl#6965
Content: @TheHotatoPotato i think the problem is ||in your statement r = (image[i][j] + ...) / 9 you're dividing by an int, so you need to make your 9 a float, either by casting (float) or making it 9.0 so that r, g, and b don't get truncated when you apply the round() function later||

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
> if you have an image that is 7 pixels wide and 1 high: ```
> 1 2 3 4 5 6 7``` and you want to reflect it, you want to swap 
> 1 and 7
> ```7 2 3 4 5 6 1```
> 2 and 6
> ```7 6 3 4 5 2 1```
> 3 and 5
> ```7 6 5 4 3 2 1
> ``` and you're done
@curiouskiwi

Author: bocajbee#6122
Content:
> Still on reflect, and it only reflects half of the image. Now, I know that I need to store the image in a temporary array or something like that, but I can't seem to fully understand the logic behind it all, and which pixels to store where in the temp array. It's bending my mind a little
@Asmodeus 

Picture it as "Scanning" over the original bitmap/array for the image, then creating a second array that stores this recorded information that's then  "mirrored" at each pixel in the original bitmap, into a new "Copy" of this bitmap. 

Then after you have an array of: 

1. The original bitmap
2. The new "copy" of this bitmap with the mirrored information 

You can then loop through the original bitmap and replace each index of that with the information at the adjacent index for each pixel in the "Copied" bitmap.

Author: Spirits#3397
Content:
why does calculation in float gets rounded down if I do it without decimal point?
float math = (27 + 28 + 28) / 3;

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Division between 2 integers in C always results in an integer

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: So 10/3 is 3

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but if one of those is a float, then you'll do float division.  10/3.0 is 3.333333

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content:
Goodness that Blur algorithm was a thing. I implemented grayscale, sepia, and reverse all in one shot last night, but then when I read Blur I knew it was time to stop and think. Went to bed, couldn't sleep, spent all night thinking of an algorithm that didn't require special cases for corners or edges. Woke up this AM, came downstairs opened a text editor, typed out my algorithm (no IDE), tested by hand with my own cases, and then ported over to the IDE. What an intense 12-hours lol

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: The nice thing about Blur is that it really pushes you to develop an elegant algorithm. Once you get it working and it passes it's super satisfying. My advice for y'all is to draw 3x3 matrices with pen and paper and work out your algorithm that way. Testing with the 600x600 images is too hard

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: Using your 3x3 matrices test with the center[1,1], upper left hand corner [0,0], and upper right hand corner at [0,2]

Content: For my solution to Blur I did not input the 4 corners. I didn't want my algorithm to have special casing for the edges or the corners. I think about it more conceptually like a moving 3x3 matrix that moves along the larger NxN matrix doing the computations. The way I described it to my friend was like a magnifying glass looking at a map and then moving the magnifying glass left to right and top to bottom. The trick is to "recognize" when the magnifying glass isn't looking at the map and to know how to ignore that data

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: I looked ahead to Speller and I'm legit nervous for that one. I have been background processing in my brain how to solve it

Author: humanbeing#0598
Content: bruh what

Author: GhostDragon#7128

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: if the center +- 1 in any direction would cause it to be outside of the image i just skipped it

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: You don't need to care about corners or edges per-se. In a NxN matrix called X you just need to consider if element Xij are within the space of N. It's like imagining that an NxN matrix has an element [-1,-1] in a "virtual space" and then ignoring that element. It's like having a sub of your NxN matrix where some of the sub elements don't exist in the space of the parent N space. Said more simply. Submatrix is a key part of how I did it and I think probably the common answer

Content: @GhostDragon exactly

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997

Author: Kiml1n#5248

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content:
> For my solution to Blur I did not input the 4 corners. I didn't want my algorithm to have special casing for the edges or the corners. I think about it more conceptually like a moving 3x3 matrix that moves along the larger NxN matrix doing the computations. The way I described it to my friend was like a magnifying glass looking at a map and then moving the magnifying glass left to right and top to bottom. The trick is to "recognize" when the magnifying glass isn't looking at the map and to know how to ignore that data
@LegendaryLootSocks

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content:
> You don't need to care about corners or edges per-se. In a NxN matrix called X you just need to consider if element Xij are within the space of N. It's like imagining that an NxN matrix has an element [-1,-1] in a "virtual space" and then ignoring that element. It's like having a sub of your NxN matrix where some of the sub elements don't exist in the space of the parent N space. Said more simply. Submatrix is a key part of how I did it and I think probably the common answer
@LegendaryLootSocks

Content: there I just quoted them

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: @jadep1103 A better way to approach the problem would be to think of each block of 9 (for which there will not always be 9) as a Submatrix of the larger Matrix (the image). So if you start at an element the elements surrounding that element (within 1 row or column) and the element itself form a sub matrix. How do you move through a matrix? With a loop nested within another loop (which is to say by height and width) so how do you move around the sub matrix? Seems like the same idea

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: @Kilrogg a Matrix is a 2D Array. A SubMatrix is just a matrix within your larger matrix. So you can think of the image as an NxN matrix (2D Array), and then when you find a pixel (element in the 2D Array) you want to change the value of, the surrounding pixels (elementals) plus itself make up a 9x9 SubMatrix (smaller 2D Array). You know how to iterate through a matrix element by element starting at [0][0] with two loops over height and width. To iterate over the sub matrix therefore is the same idea (2 loops) where the iterators are related to the starting element whose value you want to change

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: Draw a 6x6 grid. Then pick the center item in your grid and right down whats it's coordinated are. They will be [1, 1]. First row, first column is center in a 6x6 grid. Then just using math, what's the value of the top left coordinate? [0, 0]. So what's the relationship between the two? It's -1,-1. Now do that for more pixels and you'll see a pattern

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: So your program needs to do what you are doing as a human. It needs to effectively look at or visit each of the surrounding cells. You just need to tell it what the relationship is between it's starting point and where you want it to look

Kremlin_showers#1199
Content: because how integer division works in c. if you divide an int by an int then the result is simply the rounded down int for example 10/3 = 3 in C and 7 / 2 = 3 or 99 / 10 = 9. but when you use 3.0 it takes the number as a float and returns the correct value in decimal 99 / 10.0 = 9.9
